context: Small independent coffee roaster evaluating whether to pursue SCA-style specialty certification amid AI-driven commoditization.
problem_statement: Should a small coffee roaster invest capital and time to compete in standardized Specialty Coffee frameworks, or pursue an alternative identity-based strategy?
first_principles: Standardization creates efficiency but erodes differentiation.
Small actors cannot outscale systems designed for incumbents.
Meaning and narrative cannot be commoditized at the same speed as technique.
assumptions: AI-driven optimization will make 'technically correct coffee' widely accessible.
Average consumers value emotional resonance over technical scores.
Certification costs impose non-trivial capital strain on small operators.

scenarios.base: Specialty standards remain dominant but lose cultural authority.
scenarios.upside: Consumers increasingly seek local, narrative-driven coffee experiences.
scenarios.downside: Market consolidates around large brands using AI-optimized production.
scenarios.wildcard: Regulatory or cultural backlash against homogenized specialty standards.

chosen_path: Reject direct competition in standardized Specialty frameworks and instead build a narrative-first, context-driven coffee identity supported by AI for backend optimization only.
risk_assessment: Risk of limited recognition from industry insiders. Mitigated by stronger local loyalty, lower capital exposure, and narrative differentiation.
notes: This decision prioritizes identity resilience over external validation. Strategy remains adaptable if assumptions are falsified.
